description.narrative:
The realities of Europe and Africa are closely interlinked. Through migration, but also through trade, development and other policies, legal and illegal trade. More than ever before, governments, companies, financial institutions and criminal networks operate in a transnational environment. However, the media today are primarily interested in local news. International news reaches us mostly via news agencies (and goes out via them, too). News about the impact of lobbying, deals and contracts remains too superficial, unsubstantial or non-existent, due to reasons of cost and target group focus. This means that the public is not informed and that abuses or corruption very often go unnoticed. And without a well-informed public, there is no debate. You can’t change what you don’t know.When injustice, crimes against humanity, fraud are dug up and made public, society will start pressurising governments or companiesthat are falling short.
Even though it is paramount in order to map international dynamics, cross-border journalism does not fit into any existing business model. Cross-border journalism is an emerging method where journalists from different countries team up toresearch the same story and tell it to their individual target groups. The first years of experience indicate stronger reporting power, stronger impact and growing networks between journalists through the working process and meetings.
The aim of this project is to stimulate collaborative cross-border investigative journalism through research grants and networking opportunities. Internationalcollaboration will lead to a dynamic of change, at least in the international journalism community. After all, the result of an investigation will be achieved after an intense investigative collaboration that had not existed before. That collaboration can, in itself, already lead to new insights. At the same time, the stories are given publication space in the south as well as the north. Journalists are recommended to sell their story to as many news outlets as possible. Journalismfund.eu helps them with that search.
Journalists in both Europe and Africa are building professional cross-border networks, the headlines usually being investigative and/ordata journalism. Journalists within these networks will be encouraged to connect. The project does not want to replace funding for quality journalism but wants to stimulate a new method, to facilitate the establishment of informal networks between journalists andto help create landmark journalistic projects as good examples to follow.
